snippet: Aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
abstract: Aviation safety experts say discovery that two passengers on missing Malaysian airliner were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept 11, 2001; only three countries systematically screen travelers against Interpol's database of stolen passports.

byline.contributor: Andrew W. Lehren and Kitty Bennett contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline.main: Use of Stolen Passports on Missing Jet Highlights Security Flaw
headline.print_headline: Missing Airliner Said to Highlight a Security Flaw
